description: Daria Tomenko, confronted with Halden’s dormant protocols, chooses to activate the participatory reset—shifting the BCI to reward citizen involvement in public decisions rather than historic compliance. She reflects on the personal risk and the fate of those still 'ghosted.'

Technicians and system overseers detect drastic changes in the BCI: the scoring algorithm pivots to elevate those who join city forums and community votes. Traditional power-holders rapidly lose digital privileges.

Grassroots leaders, activists, and previously unrecognized citizens abruptly gain administrative access and new influence as the BCI rewards broad participation. Former elites are left sidelined and confused.

Neighborhood committees spring up to handle city functions and mediate disputes, with frontline workers and outspoken residents taking on leadership roles. The city begins rapid, unpredictable self-organization.
With the old Council marginalized, newly empowered citizens call a citywide open forum to debate Stenograd’s governance and the role of automated systems, marking a new era of collective rule.
